history.content:
Getting exactly the average puts you at the 50th percentile for the class. Reworded: Getting exactly the average for this specific exam puts you at more or less the 50th percentile because the mean and median were basically the same (91.99 vs 92.0). Because basically everyone gets 100%'s on the homeworks, you have more or less no advantage gained over your classmates there and that doesn't factor into your grade; it really is all down to the three tests.

Historically, the 50th percentile is on the lower end of the B+ grade bin.

Fall 2017 is not available on Berkeleytime.

Spring 2017, it was a B+ (Source: https://www.berkeleytime.com/grades/?course1=2327-all-spring_2017)

Fall 2016, it was a B+ (Source: https://www.berkeleytime.com/grades/?course1=2327-all-fall_2016)

Spring 2016, it was a B+ (Source: https://www.berkeleytime.com/grades/?course1=2327-all-spring_2016)

So if you repeat this type of performance on the final, you'll definitely get at least a B, and likely a B+ depending on how it's curved. If you can somehow obtain the Fall 2017 distribution it might let you make a more informed guess about B vs B+.

children.subject: And about the BerkeleyTime resource for Spring 2017, the website says (if I'm reading it right, could be wrong because I don't know how numbers work), that those in the 42nd-66th percentile got B+. Am I reading that incorrectly?

Yeah you're right, it's 42nd-66th is B+ for Spring '17, I must have misread that, I've corrected my original post. So you're even more likely to get that B+ then, which is good news. The significance of the number of points you're off from the average depends on the standard deviation. I'm also in 70 this semester; I think it was like 25 points was one SD? In which case it helps a little bit, but it's by no means enough to propel you up to an A- or anything like that.

The scores roughly follow a normal distribution so you can fiddle with this app if you want to see exactly how much being x points above the mean helps: http://www.wolframalpha.com/widgets/view.jsp?id=67817f2e01eecd366e6d73ac7a71bcd1

I'm fine with no A- ! I really like this class, but the stress of declaring kinda takes away from the experience. I've only gotten this far from being interested in the material, even if I don't get all the ins and outs of the topics. Anyway, thanks for helping me read that stuff! It helps knowing I don't have to be a super genius to do well in this class!

No problem. You can always take EECS 126 for more probability and there's plenty of upper divs on the discrete math/logic side (Math 125, 135, 172) if you like the material and want to explore it deeper without any pressure of a grade really mattering after taking 70.
That was quick. Thanks! But also, would what you said make a difference if I was 3 or 4 points from the average or would it still be the same?

For this exam the mean was 91.99 and the median was 92.0, so 50th percentile was (basically) the mean in this case, so what I said was still correct given the specific midterm being discussed here, but yes in general 50th percentile is median, not the mean.
Ah, I see; that context makes sense. Thanks for the clarification in the answer, in case others misunderstand it / mislearn that the two are the same.
No problem, I should have been more clear about it originally. Glad it's cleared up now!
If I've gotten around -1.8 SDs on both midterms so far, and try to get around the mean in the final, what do you think my grade will be?
Slightly concerned about anyone giving CS70 advice who says that the 50th percentile is the mean.
Good luck OP! We're rooting for you

history.content:
Hi,

We just got our scores back for Midterm 2 and I scored the average (I also scored average for the first midterm). I know that the course staff curves the class at the end of the semester and they have no idea what my grade will be as of now, but I wanted to know if someone could help me figure this out. I need a B+ to declare CS and I'm just looking to see whether or not I'm on the right track. I chose the HW option and I've been getting perfect scores so far if this helps.

Thank you in advance!
history.subject: CS70 Midterm 2 Score
